json_results.feasibility_analysis: Oxidizing the methyl group to an aldehyde is chemically feasible, as methyl groups adjacent to electron-withdrawing groups like sulfonyl are more susceptible to oxidation. json_results.function_group_introduce_strategy: To introduce an aldehyde functional group (-CHO), the most logical position is on the benzene ring where it can be attached without disrupting existing functional groups. json_results.feasibility_analysis: Introducing an aldehyde group para to the methoxy substituent on the benzene ring is chemically viable. Electrophilic aromatic substitution reactions, such as formylation (Gattermann-Koch or Vilsmeier-Haack reaction), can be employed to add the aldehyde group. The presence of the methoxy group, an electron-donating group, activates the benzene ring towards electrophilic substitution, making the formation of the aldehyde group feasible. Additionally, the chosen position avoids interference with the existing amide and hydroxyl functionalities.

json_results.function_group_introduce_strategy: To introduce a thiol group, we can target the carboxylate moiety, replacing the oxygen with sulfur to form a thioester. This substitution preserves the molecule's ability to interact with biological systems while introducing the desired thiol functionality.
